boardgame.name: Carrier Strike
Carrier Strike: South Pacific 1942-44
boardgame.description:
From the game manual:

CARRIER STRIKE simulates naval-air battles in the South Pacific during WWII. CARRIER STRIKE can be used to recreate historical battles or random-historical battles (battles that could have happened at a particular time). The Campaign Game allows you to complete one battle and jump immdediately into a new battle. Ships sunk or badly damaged in one battle will be unavailable for the next battle. The Campaign game allows one battle per month from May 1942 to June 1944.

In CARRIER STRIKE you issue movement orders to friendly Task Forces (TFs) and direct the Flight Operations on your carriers. Flight operations consist of selecting ordnance for bombers; moving aircraft from the hangar to the flight deck; launching aircraft on CAP, search and strike missions; and selecting or changing strike targets.

boardgame.name: Naked in Space (Bare Nekkid Edition)
boardgame.description:
From the Game's Introduction:

Welcome to the 24 Hour Role-Playing Game Naked in Space. Did the title grab you? I hope so. Any nakedness in this game is up to you, but that’s not what it’s about. The 'naked' in Naked in Space is more of a reference to the bare bones rules system, and the 'in Space' because this is Pulp Sci-Fi.

My goal with this quickie RPG is quick and simple rules and a bit of hearty emphasis on fun in a pulp sci-fi setting. And if you don't like pulp sci-fi, so what, dump the setting and use the rules. It's your game. I'm not going to go into the ins and outs of role-playing; I'm going to presume that as you've got this far you know what a Role-Playing Game is so you know what you're looking for and you know what all this nonsense is about.

From the Game's Introduction:

Every child knows that monsters are real. Not just thinks, but knows. They know that the Thing Under the Bed is waiting for them to get up in the middle of the night so that it can grab their feet and pull them, screaming, under the bed with it. They know that the Thing in the Closet is waiting for the night when the closet door isn't closed properly and it can come into the bed room and steal the child's soul. At some point when every adult grew up they forgot what it was that terrified them in the dark. They forgot the cold sweat as something scratched at the inside of the closet. It's up to the Children to stop the Monsters. No one else can.

Every child knows that they cannot fight the monsters on their own. This is why you and your friends have formed the Monster Hunter's Club. You know that if you can work together you can defeat the monsters in your neighborhood and make the nights safe for every kid at school.

boardgame.name: Carrier Force
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

Carrier Force is a game of carrier warfare in the South Pacific during World War II between Japan and the Allies (mostly U.S.).

The game includes four battles: Coral Sea, Midway, Solomons and Santa Cruz.

Carrier force may be played against a computer controlled Japanese, or by two players using the hotseat method. No Allied computer opponent is provided.

Carrier Force was one of the first games to simulate carrier warfare and was the forerunner of later games, such as Carrier Strike and the various Pacific War games by SSI and Matrix Games.

By Gary Grigsby

From the Game's Introduction:

The government tried to create a biological weapon that would self-terminate after infecting an area the size of a country. They tested it on a small area, and it forgot to kill itself.

The plague has hit. People are dying and not staying dead, or worse, mutating. Some of those who survived have gained psychic powers as an effect of the plague. boardgame.name: Gym, Tanning, Laundry: The Jersey Shore Role-playing game
boardgame.description:
From the Game's Introduction:

GTL: The Jersey Shore role-playing game allows you to become a Guido or a Guidette and experience life as a club-hopping twenty something who lives for nights and weekends. You might have a job, but it's no big deal. You work just enough to pay your bills and make it to the Shore for the weekend. With any luck, you're able to save up enough to spend a week or more at the Jersey Shore for the summer.

The game is more strongly controlled than many RPGs with characters actions governed by the Time Matrix, a weekly schedule of their activities. The Time Matrix is used to control character actions and to help pace the game. It also makes it possible to play the game with no gamemaster if desired.

It's a world where appearance is king and you are who you're with!

boardgame.name: Uncertain Worlds or: Heisenberg's Revenge
boardgame.description:
From the Game's Introduction:

The last world war ended almost as soon as the machines began to malfunction. By then, most of the old ideologues were dead - victims of their own fanaticism. Use of humankind's newest weapon, the Quantum Bomb, effected damage on a far subtler level then the cities it flattened.

A wave of subatomic chain-reactions propagated beyond the blast zones. Where the waves met they twisted and strengthened. Around the world, electrical systems began to quietly shut down and vehicles stalled out on the interstate and back-country roads. Eventually, even the lights went out.

Some side effect of the quantum weapons brought the Uncertainty Principle into the macro world. Complex machines and electronics simply stopped working. Even simple machines tended to gum up and break down when they weren't being watched.

Biological and chemical systems seem to be completely unaffected, but the damage had been done; almost overnight the technological world was plunged back into the pre-Industrial era.

Welcome to the Uncertain World.

boardgame.name: Watchmen
boardgame.description:
From the Game's Introduction:

The Age of Gears lasted long into the nineteenth century. And then the darkness came. One day, the skies darkened into night and the morning did not dawn. Darkness covered the world. Within days most higher life forms were dead or dying. Mankind had a small supply of food but in a world without refrigeration, soon mankind was dying. After a few months, the only living creatures on Earth were the clockmen. Confusion nearly did them in, there was no one left to serve. Up until then most clockmen were stationary, grandfatherly figures who taught young people in living rooms, or student from the front of university classroom. The construction factories researched better and better self-ambulating designs.

Just as suddenly as it started, the darkness ended 122 years later. During that time, the clockmen transformed themselves into the image of their former makers. Mobile clockmen wore clothes and bustled about the cities in harsh whisper of whirring gears and clanking latches. To differentiate themselves from their forefathers, the mobile clockmen started referring to themselves as watchmen. This is their story.

boardgame.name: The Ardennes Offensive
boardgame.description:
From the game manual:

THE ARDENNES OFFENSIVE is the first in a new generation of World War II operational level games from Strategic Studies Group. It is a simulation of the last great German offensive in the west, popularly known as the Ardennes Offensive or the Battle of the Bulge. The Offensive, which commenced in December 1944, achieved some early success against the surprised American forces and a limited breakthrough by German panzer elements reached Dinant on the Meuse River - albeit temporarily. Without adequate air cover or supply, and against a battle hardened and resolute opponent, the plan was fore-doomed to failure but some 100,000 Americans, and an even greater number of Germans, would fall before the last blitzkrieg was stopped and the inexorable Allied drive to Berlin resumed.

The game's scenarios cover the most exciting aspects of the battle, including a campaign game which allows you to refight the entire conflict. A tutorial scenario covering the initial German drive to Bastogne takes you through the game mechanics.

boardgame.name: Battle at Bull Run
boardgame.description:
(From the website)

The first major battle of the Civil war, Bull Run (also known as First Manassas) was a contest of tactical opportunities lost. Featuring a brilliant flanking march by Union forces under General Irvin McDowell that caught the Confederate General Beauregard by surprise on his weak east flank, the Union army failed to roll up the Confederate line due, in great measure, to the famous stand by General Thomas Jackson's Virginia brgade, which was said to have stood "like a stone wall". On the other side of the tactical ledger, General Beauregard's plan to drive across Bull Run on the west side to Centerville, thus cutting the Union army off from its supplies and communications, failed due to poorly communicated orders. Battle at Bull Run is a simulation of historical events of July 21, 1861 intended to give a feeling for the historical decisions required by the two army commanders in a fast play format.

* Two-Person or Solitaire Play
* Color Five-Page Game Rules Manual
* Upgraded Game Map In Full Color
* Larger Game Map Now 15 x 11 Hexes
* 25 Upgraded 3/4" Counters
* Two Union Units Added To Order of Battle
* Solitaire Play Rules
* Available in PDF Format

boardgame.name: Task Force 1942
boardgame.description:
Task Force 1942: Surface Naval Action in the South Pacific is a DOS PC game, released by MPS Labs (MicroProse) in 1992.

The game is a surface naval simulation which allows the player to operate single ships or a task force made up of ships, from the United States Navy (USN), Royal Australian Navy (RAN) and Royal New-Zealand Navy (RNZN), or the Imperial Japanese Navy (IJN) in the South Pacific during WWII. It was designed to run under PC-DOS or MS-DOS, version 5.0 or higher. The specific historical setting was the series of ferocious naval engagements fought around the largest island in the Solomon Islands chain, Guadalcanal, in 1942, including the following:

Battle of Tassafaronga
Battle of Empress Augusta Bay
Naval Battle of Vella Lavella
Battle of Savo Island
Battle of Cape Esperance
First and Second Naval Battle of Guadalcanal
Battle of Kula Gulf

Source: Wikipedia, "Task Force 1942", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: The General
boardgame.description:
From the Back of the Game Box:

By Ian Williams.

A 3D graphical representation of warfare in the Napoleonic era.

In 'The General' you see the conflict unfold before you from a first-person point of view. Distant troops are only identifiable by using a telescope, units may be obscured by buildings, orders take time to reach the units to which they have been issued and reports from your Brigade Commanders may be lost on their way back to you.

These features along with many others, make 'The General' exceptional. The standard 'birds-eye view' has been replaced by the 'General's-eye view' and communication problems added to give the players a taste of the real difficulties faced by the generals of that time.

Assume the role of The General of the Grand Army and experience the authentic atmosphere of Napoleonic Warfare.

boardgame.name: Sky Kid
スカイキッド
boardgame.description:
Sky Kid (スカイキッド, Sukai Kiddō) is a horizontal scrolling shooter arcade game that was released by Namco in 1985. It runs on Namco Pac-Land hardware but with a video system like that used in Dragon Buster. It is also the first game from Namco to allow 2 players to play simultaneously. The game was later released on the Famicom (brought to the American NES by Sunsoft), and both this version and the original arcade version were later released on Nintendo's Virtual Console service.

Sky Kid is a two-dimensional, scrolling shooter game. The players play as the Sky Kids "Red Baron" and "Blue Max", which are references to Manfred von Richthofen, the famous World War I flying ace, and the prestigious order Pour le Mérite, informally known as Blue Max. The Sky Kids fly around in biplanes and are assigned specific targets during the missions. These missions involve bombing specific targets. The "A" button is used to control the plane's machine gun and the "B" button is used to perform a loop.

A number of obstacles face the player in each level. First, their biplane is not equipped with a bomb to complete their mission, and must be picked up en route to the target. Second, there are both ground and air units that attempt to keep the Sky Kids from accomplishing their mission. Last, the Sky Kids may have to navigate through some very inhospitable terrain or navigate around cities in order to get to the target. The targets that the Sky Kids must bomb will either be a fortress complex or a ship. As the player moves farther up in the 9 missions, multiple targets will begin to appear in the course of one mission. Players receive points for destroying air and ground targets, receiving additional points for how many of these types of targets are destroyed. In addition, players get points based on how much of the target is destroyed.

Sometimes blowing up enemy units will reveal a hidden Namco icon or character, including Pac-Man, Inky, the Special Flag from Rally-X (which has appeared in many other Namco games) or Pooka from Dig Dug.

If the player does a loop in front of girls, the girls send out hearts representing kisses. If the player shoots them, they turn into waving dogs.

Source: Wikipedia, "Sky Kid," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Flags The Game
Prof Géo
boardgame.description:
User Summary:
Before starting, the players decide the number of countries to "complete" in order to win the game. To complete a country the player must obtain all all three types of cards belonging to said country. The three cards are the flag, the coat of arms, and the capital.

There are two phases of play, the "road" and the "boardwalk".

The Road:
Players roll the dice and move their peg along the road traveling through 85 countries that existed during the mid 1980's. When players land on a country, they must choose which card they think they can correctly guess. When the player guesses correctly, the player obtains said card.

The Boardwalk:
A person can only move to the boardwalk when they have the necessary number of cards. For instance, if the players agreed upon 3 countries to complete, the player must obtain 3 cards of the coat of arms, 3 of the flags, and 3 of the capitals (it doesn't matter if they are of the same country or not). During the boardwalk the players have chances to take away cards from other players and to correctly guess the remaining types of cards of the countries the player has already obtained cards for.

From the Box:
Capitals - Flags - Coat of Arms in Flags The Game

For the teen who has to learn geography!
For the adult who wants to know more!
A fun game for everyone no matter what is your knowledge about geography.
You can play easily and with fun, because, Flags The Game makes a brain without strain.

boardgame.name: Weimar: German Politics 1929-1933
boardgame.description:
October, 1929: The Republic is crumbling. With the death of Gustav Stresemann on October 3, 1929 and the crash of the American Stock Exchange, Germany's recovery from the devastating Great War now is in doubt. Communist, Fascist and Republican forces clash over ideology and erupt into a war of words and violence. Unemployment begins to spiral out of control while the German people grow restless. Rallies are held by charismatic leaders as lawmakers struggle to find answers. Amongst the chaos, a new figure will head the German nation.

Weimar: German Politics 1929-1933 is a two-player political game that tries to simulate the chaos of Germany prior to Hitler's appointment to chancellor. Will you take the role of the Social Democratic leadership, staving off the extreme ideologies of Communism and Fascism? Using your political influence and paramilitary forces, will you try to gain control of the Reichstag, or send Germany to the brink of anarchy? Can you change history, or is Germany doomed to repeat it?

Weimar is a block/CDG in which one side plays the SPD and the other plays the NSDAP. A third Communist force is played by both players. Players hold rallies, street fights, build alliances, and try to win the hearts and minds of the German people.

Victory can be achieved in multiple ways, with both parties being able to gain influence in each electoral area and score them in each election phase. Influence is gained by holding rallies and bringing political and paramilitary forces to both "encourage" and intimidate the German people. Alternatively for the Nazis, they can use events to increase chaos and unrest in order to bring down the weak parliamentary government. For the SPD, they can use special actions to stop the Nazi political machine, including the elimination of its leadership.

boardgame.name: Cogsburg
boardgame.description:
Designer Summary:

For ages, the studious inhabitants of Cogsburg lived without fear, happily ticking along as they went about their business. But now a freak accident has occurred at the Cogtower, scattering cogs all over town and sending the clockwork winders into chaos. The Cogmen must repair the Cogtower before it is too late.

Each player directs a handful of resourceful Cogmen to gather cogs and repair the Cogtower. Each turn, a Winding card will be drawn from the deck, and any Cogmen standing adjacent to a Winder will be wound up by that amount, gaining Energy. Once all the Winding cards have been used, a Rainy Day card is added and the deck is reshuffled. If a Rainy Day card is drawn, any Cogmen who don’t find shelter will get wet and rust (a terrible fate!)

Beginning with the starting player, players take turns moving all of their Cogmen, who must spend Energy to move. At the end of the turn, any Cogmen dangerously low on Energy (and not near a Winder) may make a Desperation move, one last push towards a Winder before becoming unwound. A Cogman that becomes unwound is inoperable until he is wound up by an ally.

Cogmen gather the cogs that are scattered about Cogsburg, returning them to the Cogtower to gain victory points, or he may choose to repair a broken/rusted Cogman instead. A Cogman can only carry a single cog at a time (They’re very heavy!)

Once the Cogtower has been rebuilt, final scores are tallied. Each player recieves one Victory Point for every cog they supplied to the Cogtower, plus an additional point for each operable Cogman.

The basic game is for two players. Rules for three players and four-player team play are included. Official rules for entirely cooperative play are forthcoming.

boardgame.name: Ghouls 'n' Ghosts
大魔界村
boardgame.description:
The gameplay for Ghouls 'n Ghosts is similar to that of Ghosts 'n Goblins. The player controls the knight Arthur, who must advance through a series of eerie levels and defeat a number of undead and demonic creatures in his quest to restore the souls stolen by Lucifer (Loki in the English-language Genesis/Mega Drive and Sega Master System versions), including the soul of his lover, Princess Prin Prin. Along the way, Arthur can pick up a variety of weapons and armor to help him in his quest.

To defeat the game, Arthur must complete the game twice. The first time completion allows a special weapon to appear in the next round of play. To enter Lucifer's chamber the player must have this special weapon equipped and must have defeated the final Fly boss from level 5. After entering the final large door, the player goes directly to Lucifer's chamber.

While the core gameplay remains the same as its predecessor, the game now allows Arthur to fire directly upward and directly downward while in mid air.

By jumping in certain spots, players can cause a treasure chest to erupt from the ground. By firing his weapon at the chest, players may uncover new weapons, gold armor or an evil magician that changes Arthur into an elderly man or a helpless duck. The gold armor allows players to charge up the weapon to release a powerful magical attack. Each weapon has its own special attack.

Source: Wikipedia, "Ghouls 'n Ghosts", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Gauntlet II
boardgame.description:
The gameplay is very similar to the original Gauntlet, a topdown dungeon crawl supporting up to four players. The biggest difference from the original game is that players can choose identical classes, instead of being limited to a particular one for each joystick; the players being differentiated by colors. Thus, instead of having a "warrior", "wizard", and "valkyrie" (for instance), in Gauntlet II there could be a "red wizard", a "blue elf" and a "green warrior".

In addition to the new "class" system, new level designs were added, including the possibility of encountering them in altered ways by having the playfield turned in steps of 90°. Level 100 was the winning design from a public competition. Other new features included the enemy "It", which upon contact would make a player "It" and draw all enemies towards him/her. The only way to release this curse is by touching another player or entering the exit, turning any level containing "It" into a fantasy filled game of tag. Other notable additions include the ability to ricochet shots off walls by means of a special pick-up, acid puddles that caused large, predetermined amounts of damage and a large dragon which would occupy multiple squares and require multiple hits to destroy.
New level elements were also added, adding more variety to the original game. These included "all walls are invisible", "magic walls" which changed into monsters or items when hit, "stun tiles" which stunned the player, and exits which flashed from functioning to non-functioning. This sequel was also the first to feature what is now known as the Gauntlet theme tune, which resembles a simplified Baroque fugue.

Source: Wikipedia, "Gauntlet II", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Quest for Glory V: Dragon Fire
Quest for Glory V: Fogo do Dragão
boardgame.description:
The Rites of Rulership are about to commence, and the victor will be given the crown. The Hero enters the contest with the assistance of Erasmus, Rakeesh, and many old friends from previous entries in the series. The Hero competes against competitors Kokeeno Pookameeso, Magnum Opus, Gort, and Elsa Von Spielburg (who returns from the first game.)

As the Rites commence, however, an unknown assassin begins systematically picking off each of the contestants. Each contestant is murdered by a poison dagger, and they all are murdered near Dragon Pillars, the objects used to keep the Dragon of Silmaria locked up. After completing the third Rite, defeating the Hydra, Rakeesh is attacked by the assassin and, depending on the course of action chosen by the player, either lives or dies.The conspiracy is eventually unraveled and the Dragon, having been released due to the destruction of the Dragon Pillars, is defeated.

...

The fifth game is arguably a different genre from the first four; while the first four are mostly adventure games incorporating role-playing elements; the fifth game is a role-playing game incorporating some adventure elements. For instance, the fifth game has a wide variety of weapons, armor and magical items, whereas the first four do not. Also, in the fifth game nearly every major mission consists of going to some place and defeating some monster in physical or magical combat. Additionally, the controls and battle system are substantially different from those of the first three games and have taken the variations of the fourth game even further.

Also differentiating the fifth game from the first four were an impressive soundtrack by Emmy-winning composer Chance Thomas and a new graphics engine programmed by Eric Lengyel.

Source: Wikipedia, "Quest for Glory V: Dragon Fire", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Mega Man Anniversary Collection
boardgame.description:
Mega Man Anniversary Collection a compilation of video games developed by Atomic Planet Entertainment and published by Capcom. It was released exclusively in North America on June 23, 2004 for the Nintendo GameCube and Sony PlayStation 2 (PS2) and on March 15, 2005 for the Microsoft Xbox. Mega Man Anniversary Collection contains the first eight games in the original Mega Man series, which debuted on the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) with the first six games, moved to the Super Nintendo Entertainment System (SNES) with the seventh game, and then moved again to the PlayStation and Sega Saturn with the eighth game. The plot follows the robotic protagonist Mega Man in his continuing adventures battling the evil Dr. Wily and his army of Robot Masters.

Each game has a nearly identical gameplay structure in which the player traverses a series of themed stages to face off against boss robots, gain new weapons and abilities, then defeat Dr. Wily in a final confrontation. An extra feature is the "Navi Mode" for the first six titles, which provides hints and pathways for completing each stage. In addition to these eight games, Mega Man Anniversary Collection includes two unlockable fighting games (Mega Man: The Power Battle and Mega Man 2: The Power Fighters), which were both previously unreleased outside of Japan. These two titles are similar in gameplay but a bit more streamlined. The battles cut straight to the bosses, who get progressively more difficult with each one defeated. Other unlockables in the Mega Man Anniversary Collection include original artwork and remixed music.

Source: Wikipedia, "Mega Man Anniversary Collection", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Metroid: Other M
boardgame.description:
The game takes place between Super Metroid and Metroid Fusion. Other M opens with a cinematic showing the final battle with Mother Brain at the conclusion of Super Metroid. After escaping the exploding Planet Zebes, Samus Aran awakens on a Galactic Federation ship. After leaving, she receives a distress signal, commonly coded as "Baby's Cry", from a dormant "Bottle Ship", which is floating a short distance away from a Federation vessel.

Gameplay is designed to allow switching between first person and third person views based on how the Wii remote is held. Environments are 3D, and Other M is the first game in the franchise to feature melee combat.

boardgame.description:
Alternate Reality: The City is an RPG by Philip Price primarily developed for the Atari 8-bit. It featured a number of technological breakthroughs and an intriguing storyline.

It was to be the first of six or seven releases in the Alternate Reality series, but only it and the sequel The Dungeon were ever released.

The City opened with a cinematic sequence of being abducted by an alien ship, then stepping through a portal which assigned your stats. After that, it became a fantasy RPG set in the city of Xebec's Demise.

boardgame.name: Alternate Reality: The Dungeon
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

Alternate Reality: The Dungeon, by Philip Price, is the sequel to the RPG AR: The City. Originally designed as a single game, the publisher Datasoft split it into a sequel.

The Dungeon featured improved graphics and gameplay over the original, and featured an extensive 4-level dungeon to explore. The game was from a first-person 3-d dungeon perspective.

The Alternate Reality series was originally conceived to have many further sequels which delved further into the storyline, but these were never fully developed.

Cards changed into tiles, main board and player boards.

boardgame.name: Zero Zap
boardgame.description:
Zero Zap is a pinball-like game where players position an arrow and launch it into the playing area. The arrow then bounces around hitting point targets, ranging from 0-9 points, and deflecting off of walls. Each time a point target is hit, it changes into an X, which then becomes a point target again, of a random value, when hit.

Players try to get as high of a score as possible with a limited number of times in which the arrow can be launched. If a player lands back onto the starting area, they launch again. If a player hits a point target of 0, the arrow falls back to the starting area, ready to be launched.

The game featured a mode for customizing the play area.

Source: User summary

boardgame.name: Tigers on the Prowl 2
Tigers on the Prowl II
boardgame.description:
From the back of the game box:

Tigers on the Prowl is detailed. It's unlike anything you've ever experienced before. The scope is the ENTIRE Eastern Front in World War II, from the invasion of Poland in 1939 to the fall of Berlin in 1945 - including ALL of the Armies involved! German, SS, Luftwaffe, Soviet, Guards, and Axis satellites. Forces are chosen from hundreds of fighting vehicles, weapons, aircraft, and force structures that were oreven could have been used on the Eastern Front.

Tigers on the Prowl is realistic. Set at one of the most demanding combat scales, (above company and below division), both strategy AND tactics must be meshed to achieve success. With each player commanding up to a brigade-level task force, inicluding supporting units such as artillery and aircraft, the options and challenges are endless. Combat orders must be issued through a "chain of command" to subordinate company, platoon and section sized units.

Tigers on the Prowl is accurate. Combat is resolved by detailed calculations based on the same principals used by the U.S. Army Ballistics Research Lab and combat planners. These calculations take into account actual armor thickness and round penetration at the instant of impact, weight of explosive, fragmentation effects, environmental conditions, and more.

Tigers on the Prowl is easy to use. Designed for all levels of wargamers, Tigers on the Prowl includes 5 scenarios, a built-in scenario builder, and three levels of difficulty. It also includes automatic set-ip, movement and targeting options.

Tigers on the Prowl is as real as you can get without being there.

User Addendum:

The game box for Tigers on the Prowl v2 (and hence, the text above) is the same as the original Tigers on the Prowl, but with a small, round "Version 2" sticker attached.
Tigers on the Prowl v2 uses the same game manual as it's sister game, Panthers in the Shadows.

boardgame.name: Panthers in the Shadows
PitS
boardgame.description:
From the back of the game box:

Panthers in the Shadows is an advanced simulation that re-creates World War II tactical level combat in Western Europe, the Mediterranean, and North Africa from 1939 to 1945. The scale defaults are platoon/section units, 1 minute turns, and 100 meter hexes, although players may customize the first two conditions. Extremely flexible, Panthers in the Shadows can portray anything from a quick patrol size engagement to a day-long battle between two divisions.

Panthers in the Shadows is much more than just a game. It is an excruciatingly accurate and comprehensive representation. Historical force structures are included for the United States, British Commonwealth, France, Belgium, The Netherlands, Germany, and Italy. Over 1500 different weapon systems of all types are available, including small arms, tanks, artillery, guns, rockets, spotter and strike aircraft, landing craft, amphibious vehicles, and warships. Even more impressive, every single weapon is painstakingly modeled for movement, ballistic, protection, and general characteristics.

With the depth that Panthers in the Shadows provides, the challenges come naturally. Forget about learning to beat a "game system" - because real-life tactics produce the same results in Panthers in the Shadows as they did historically. Also forget about having a force that unthinkingly and instantly responds to your commands. In Panthers in the Shadows your force behaves like real soldiers that are affected by morale, the command structure, and other intangible factors. Like no other commercially available computer wargame, Panthers in the Shadows places you squarely in the Commander's position. It is truly a unique and innovative interactive tool to study and explore military history.

Panthers in the Shadows - It's not over until the smoke clears!

Title: Keepers of Darkness

So, the term 'demonic headache' doesn't mean anything to you? Hmm... I think a thorough tour in Demon City is in order. Of course we'll also have time to visit the City of the Dead and the Charibs, pale-makeduped cannibals. Did I mention the Wich Barons or the Dark Colossuses. No? Better not...Well, shall we?

"The world of the Thunder Age has a distinctly steampunk feel. The world has recently-and drastically-changed from medieval swords-and-sorcery to a mixed renaissance and Industrial Revolution tech level. Flintlocks and muskets are the best weapons an adventurer can hope for, but there are extremely expensive, very powerful machine guns called "storm cannons." The world has also recently fallen under the effects of the "Darkfall", an event causing thousands of demons or "nocturnals" to enter the world, along with Corrupted, those who have made a deal with the forces of the Darkfall for power-and usually a curse of some sort."

boardgame.name: Herland: Perfect Genetic Utopia
boardgame.description:
Publisher's description:

Welcome to a world split in two, where women live in harmony in Greater North America while men live across the sea in a society of their own. The society of women seems perfect, but what is the true cost of their luxury and peace? There's a war going on, a war hidden from the public view. And if that doesn't draw you in, how about this: all of the PCs must be female.
Herland: Perfect Genetic Utopia is a futuristic RPG setting designed for use with the QAGS 2nd Edition rules. This PDF includes detailed descriptions of the Greater North American government and society, as well as description of the Underground rebellion, rules for playing both sides, tips and optional rules for playing an all-female campaign with male players, plot ideas for your campaign, an introductory adventure, sample Words and GMCs, a fancy new character sheet, and hilarious generalizations about the fairer sex.

boardgame.name: Tales of the OSS: The Train
boardgame.description:
Publisher's description:

TALES OF THE OSS: The Train is our first Adventure Pack for Simply Roleplaying! Author Mike DeSanto has created a tense World War II adventure where the players are daring opeatives of the OSS (precursors to today's Special Forces), inserted behind enemy lines to stop a strategically-critical Nazi train.

As OSS officers, players must make contact with a band of brave but headstrong members of the French Resistance, win their confidence, train them in their special brand of undercover tactics, and lead them in a number of missions to stop the Nazis in their tracks. Based on historical stories of this amazing group of freedom fighters, TALES OF THE OSS: The Train offers drama and excitement of a different kind for players and gamemasters who may be tired of the same old dungeons.

The package comes complete with new weapons and equipment cards, character sheets for some pre-designed player characters (or you can create your own using the Simply Roleplaying! rules), important handouts and pullouts for ease of play, and even a set of black-and white cardstock figures of OSS operatives, resistance fighters and Nazi forces. Artwork by Jeremy McHugh adds a great touch of historical atmosphere to this great adventure package.

Protect your cornfields and lock up your livestock, because FLOCK is here!
Pilot a UFO around vibrantly-colored landscapes in this charming sandbox puzzle game where you must herd animal life back to the Motherflocker.
Using a powerful physics engine that drives many of the game’s elements, FLOCK features over 50 pastoral puzzles.
Pick up wood to form bridges, move boulders to create obstructions, and flatten fields into pathways all to help deliver your herd before time runs out!
Flock together with a friend and even create and share your own crazy levels online!
Herd, poke, prod and manipulate cute, cuddly animals that react to each other and their hazardous surroundings
Over 50 levels of pastoral puzzle challenges
2 player local co-op flocking
Level editor allows for custom puzzles to be created, shared and rated
Compelling environments complemented by a whimsical art style, beautiful lighting and distinctive textures makes this one of the most graphically-advanced downloadable titles to date
Real-world physics engine creates all new types of puzzles; Pick up wood to form bridges, move boulders to create obstructions, and flatten fields into pathways
Lots of fun surprises, secret collectibles and upgrades to find

Source: The Publisher Website.

boardgame.name: Ottocento
boardgame.description:
Ottocento is a Tarot game for 4 players which comes from Bologna. Tarot games have been played in that city for over 500 years, and the game of Ottocento as currently played preserves distinct characteristics (both of the games and of the pack of cards) which go back at least to the 16th century. The special 62-card pack that is used and the game itself are often known as Tarocchino (pronounced tarokino), the diminutive form of Tarocco referring to the reduction of the pack from 78 to 62 cards.

Ottocento is a point-trick game, with trumps. The cards have point values individually (as in other Tarot games) but also score in combinations. There is no bidding, but players can score by declaring card combinations held in their hands at the start of play, as well as for combinations taken in tricks.

(* Ragnarök is the apocalypse in Scandinavian mythology.)

boardgame.name: Metal Shogi
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

Gameplay: A shogi variant that adds dice-driven combat, modified by using effect cards (only one card--selected at the beginning of the game). Figures are pewter. Collect figures (power levels from 1 to 5) to construct your 5-combatant team (using two of six colors). More powerful characters can only be summoned if a certain number of colors are on the table.

Theme: Uses characters from Dragon Ball Kai, pitting one team of combatants against another. The same character can be found across multiple colors, roughly corresponding to allegiances found in the manga (comics). For example, Goku is found in both a low power level and a high power level (super), but even characters without supers are represented.

Goal: There are two variants, basic and advanced. In the basic, simply having characters breakthrough (reach the opponent's starting line) completes the game. In the advanced, there are three win conditions, including having the majority of your characters occupying the Dragon Ball area in the middle of the playing field.

Components: There are preconstructed starters (currently 3 available), and booster singles (currently 2 available). Starters include 5 figures (using two colors), a die, a double-sided effect card, a rule sheet, and a play mat (paper). The third starter play mat sports different coloring and English. Singles include a figure and a tip sheet showing how all the figures from the set might be used.
